------=_NextPart_000_003A_01C3C254.64B809D0
Content-Type: text/plain;
	charset="iso-8859-1"
Content-Transfer-Encoding: quoted-printable

Mitchell,

You wrote:
>You will spoil your lurker status with such well wri=
tten posts! :)

Thank you for the compliment.


You wrote:
> Fogel's book i=
s what inspired me to work on neuroevolution.

Yeah, Fogel was very persuas=
ive in my looking much more closely at GA.  I had essentially discounted GA=
s and was going with just ANN training.  After reading his work, I then tri=
ed to replicate his structure only targeting 5X5 Go instead of checkers.  A=
fter many many iterations and discovering error after error in my framework=
, I finally decided the fastest way to debug my framework was to replicate =
Fogel's experiments and then gently extend them in the directions in which =
I am interested.  And then finally jump to Go.  I may do a couple of other =
games in between just to get practice generating encoding techniques.


You=
 wrote:
> I suppose your generic game player is in C++?

My framework is wr=
itten entirely in Java (currently 1.4.2_02).  After doing some experimentat=
ion, I decided that the 5-10% I might save using C++ (or Borland's Delphi) =
would be completely wasted in my having to hand code a fragile distributed =
processing mechanism.  And then update it frequently or resort to massive a=
mounts of "on-the-wire" translation code for each of my architectures.  I d=
eplore than kind of work...I get totally demotivated with too many tangents=
 like that.

So, I have written my own distributed computing mechanism usin=
g RMI/Serialization.  I did not find anything I was willing to use at the t=
ime I wrote it (this time last year).  I have had up to 6 machines working =
simultaneously playing out games and reporting back the results to the main=
 generation processing node.  They did 1,000 generations (150,000 games of =
checkers at 4 ply) in a little less than 6 days.  I was quite pleased with =
the efficiency.  Fogel had to wait months.  And my system is very scalable.=
  I can add PIII 450 box after PIII 450 box and it scales almost perfectly =
linearly until the network itself becomes the bottleneck.  And I am using 1=
0mb right now.  I will switch to full duplex 100mb just as soon as I am mai=
nly focused on just experiments (as opposed to framework tangents) and have=
 at least 10 boxes working.

And Sun is continuing to improve the Hotspot J=
VM.  It is getting closer and closer to hand-written optimized C++ code...t=
here are many cases now, where it matches or surpasses compiler optimized C=
++ code (except Intel's C++/C compiler).  An expert C++ coder doing very sp=
ecific highly technical optimization (which generally means dropping back t=
o C and denormalizing classes to gain maximum efficiency) can still gain a =
5-10% advantage on Sun's Hotspot JVM.  

IBM's JVM actually outperforms Sun=
's Hotspot in a couple of areas (one of which is float/double computation),=
 or did.  I will eventually be using jMocha (IBM Open Source software) to a=
ctually test out the ideal JVM and configuration for each node in my networ=
k so as to eak out maximum speed at the node level.  First priority, I just=
 want to replicate Fogel's original design.  It has been a long trail getti=
ng here.  I am so bloody close, finally.  I am taking the week of Christmas=
 and the week of New Years off.  Can you guess what I will be doing that 16=
 days?  You get three chances and the first two don't count!  ;^)

Thanks t=
o Java's RMI code mobility, I am able to have "dumb" nodes that actually on=
ly have the Java JVM installed.  Then, I created a small batch file (4 line=
s) on each node.  The batch file is fired up (or more than one, if the node=
 has multiple processors) and fetches its entire context from the master no=
de, including the appropriate game related class files, to start processing=
.  This means I can vary my experiments between player architectures and ev=
en game types without having to go to each node and "code update" it to kee=
p it in version sync (if you have ever experienced this, you would know the=
 complete nightmare library version synchronization can end up being).  Jav=
a is highly valuable in this way.  It makes distributing work to other comp=
uters *much* less fragile than is my experience with other languages (C++ a=
nd Delphi are the two immediate ones I have presonal experience with...and =
a little Eiffel...I love Bertrand Meyer's work...I have read Object Oriente=
d Software Construction c1997 3 times...wow, what an OO genius).

I am very=
 close (less than 10 hours of coding time, hopefully) to having finally rep=
licated Fogel's original design (non-spatial).  And then to do the spatial =
is less than 20 minutes of additional code work and about 6 days of waiting=
 for it to process then 1,000 generations.

I am still having to do stupid =
tangent work frequently.  Right now, I am on a tangent to re-write the gene=
ration storage mechanism as it keeps overflowing the master nodes HD with +=
9GBs of data doing a 1,000 generation run (takes around 6 days).  The re-wr=
ite is having each generation stored in a .zip file (compression) so it wil=
l reduce the amount of actual HD space used to about 20% of what it was bef=
ore.  Again, Java has a built-in API to handle all the zip file management.=
 And I intend on having the file output occuring on another thread so as to=
 not bog down the primary thread's job of distributing work to the other no=
des.  I have been very diligent about using Java's multi-threading techniqu=
es to maximize my ability to use a Player instance in games or descendants =
at the same time it is also being written out via a stream to wherever.  Th=
at was more a multi-threading design technique from Effective Java than it =
was the Java language or APIs.

I am having a great time with this.


You w=
rote:
>I strongly suggest staying away from full-board Go, at least for the=
 next decade.  If you want some chance of success, I recommend 5x5 first-ca=
pture Go.

I agree wholeheartedly.  Scott (a friend working with me) and I =
have both been focused on starting with 5x5 once we get to Go.  In fact, we=
 are going to try to use the whole "3 level Go training technique" (of whic=
h Capture Go is the first level) to see what kinds of directions that might=
 take us.  As to waiting a decade...likely...and the wait will be on the me=
ga-computers doing the evolution...hopefully!  LOL!


Well, I must go...Yin=
yang is calling me (name of my AI/GA/ANN framework).

Oh, and I intend to O=
pen Source my entire framework under the GPL once I feel the design is suff=
iciently mature.  Right now, it is just a straight through hack so I can ge=
t to GA/ANN experimentation.


Jim O'Flaherty


  ----- Original Message --=
--- 
  From: Mitchell Timin 
  To: neat@yahoogroups.com 
  Sent: Sunday, De=
cember 14, 2003 12:34 PM
  Subject: Re: [neat] board games


  --- "Jim O'F=
laherty, Jr." <jim_oflaherty_jr@...>
  wrote:
  > Mitchell,
  > 
  > =
I have not spoken much in this group.  I am a lurker
  > and intend on usin=
g NEAT in the future.  For now, I
  > am using simple feedforward networks =
making an
  > evaluation of a board state with a ply management
  > system.=
  I am replicating the experiments in the
  > book Blondie24 by David Fogel=
.  I have developed a
  > framework for playing "generic" perfect informati=
on
  > non-random two player games.  My first
  > implementation is obvious=
ly checkers.  My goal
  > implemetation is Go.

  You will spoil your lurke=
r status with such well
  written posts! :)

  Fogel's book is what inspire=
d me to work on
  neuroevolution.

  I suppose your generic game player is =
in C++?

  > My gut feel on your assertion is that I agree.  I
  > sense th=
at min/max (or some specialization of it
  > like Alpha/Beta) will likely b=
e present in more
  > complex game playing ANNs.  It seems it would take
  =
> an enormous amount of searching in a game space for
  > a GA to have an A=
NN of any type converge to the
  > min/max mechanism regardless of the ANN
=
  > meta-architecture approach.  In fact, it seems more
  > likely for an A=
NN using GA to attempt to use the
  > pattern recognition approach many tim=
es before
  > stumbling on a rudimentary version of min/max (it
  > would r=
equire recurrent connections in the ANN and
  > in unique combinations).

 =
 A recurrent architecture, such as NEAT can create,
  might be able to deve=
lop the equivalent of 1-ply
  look-ahead, which would be adequate for tic-t=
ac-toe. 
  I think this is worth attempting, and would be an
  advancement =
of the state-of-the-art. 

  > However, I do think that it is possible for =
ANNs to
  > suggest moves at which to take a deeper look.  For
  > example,=
 in the domain of Go, there are way too many
  > possible moves for even a =
full ply search of depth 2
  > to yield any level of effectiveness.  The br=
eadth of
  > available "legal" moves in Go starts at 361 and
  > stays abov=
e 100 for almost the entire game.  Worse,
  > thanks to captures and Ko, th=
e number of legal moves
  > is not guaranteed to descend.

  This is a very=
 good idea!

  I strongly suggest staying away from full-board Go, at
  lea=
st for the next decade.  If you want some chance of
  success, I recommend =
5x5 first-capture Go. 
  (First-capture is the variation where the game end=
s if
  any stone or stones are captured.)  There are no KO's,
  and clearly=
 finite length games, yet this game is
  challenging.  (and you can move up=
 to 7x7)

  Connect 4 seems like a good game to work on.  Many
  people kno=
w it.  There are several websites where one
  can play vs. a computer.  The=
re are only 7 possible
  moves per turn.  The games are much shorter than
 =
 chess, checkers or Go.  Yet the game is far from
  trivial.

  > As such, =
some sort of mechanism to priortize looking
  > at some subset of "legal" m=
oves is essential (if you
  > are familiar with Go, you could refer to the
=
  > patterns described in "Go Proverbs").  I suspect an
  > ANN that specia=
lizes in small regional patterns will
  > likely be able to be evolved that=
 reduces the
  > "legal" move set substantially.  Even then, it would
  > n=
eed to reduce it to less than 3% FOR EACH PLY DEPTH
  > to make a ply searc=
h depth of 6 or 8 even reasonable
  > computationally.  That is one hell of=
 an efficiency,
  > +97% *accurate* reduction in legal moves.
  > 
  > At t=
he present time, I am sort of seeing an ANN
  > sandwich; ANN #1 takes a se=
t of all legal moves and
  > prioritizes them.  A ply manager then recursiv=
ely
  > calls ANN #1 until it reaches a certain depth.  Then
  > the ply ma=
nager presents the resultant board state
  > to ANN #2 for a full board eva=
luation.  This cycle
  > continues until a move is deemed most effective an=
d
  > then utilized.
  > 
  > The way in which ANN #1 evolves (mutation and=
/or
  > feedback on a fixed topology, direct encoding using
  > NEAT, indir=
ect encoding using many different types
  > of topological techniques inclu=
ding NEAT) can be
  > completely different from the way in which ANN #2
  >=
 evolves.  This produces a meta-GA GA approach; a GA
  > for discovering th=
e ideal GA techinique for each of
  > the two ANNs.  As you can imagine, we=
 now have a
  > HUGE computational space.  And this assumes two ANNs
  > an=
d some form of the min-max algorithm.  And there
  > are other "techniques"=
 for capturing static patterns
  > in a pattern matching DB that might be m=
ore
  > efficient in the long run.

  Using more than one ANN for an applic=
ation makes good
  sense.  We now know that the mammalian brain is
  organi=
zed in many distince modules that communicate
  with each other.  We can do=
 that with ANNs.  In fact I
  have run some experiments with two ANNs solvi=
ng my
  4play puzzle.  (two 22 neuron ANNs instead of one 44
  neuron ANN).=
  First results were encouraging.  It is a
  way of substantially reducing =
the number of weights.


  =3D=3D=3D=3D=3D
  Mitchell Timin
  http://annevo=
lve.sourceforge.net

  __________________________________

e@yahoogroups.com

erms of Service.

  PM</DIV>
  <DIV style=3D"FONT: 10pt arial"><B>Subject:</=
B> Re: [neat] board games</DIV>

ations).<BR><BR>A recurrent architecture, such as NEAT can

ght be able to develop the equivalent of 1-ply<BR>look-ahead,

  I do think that it is possible for ANNs to<BR>> suggest moves at whic=
h to 
  take a deeper look.  For<BR>> example, in the domain of Go,=
 there are 
  way too many<BR>> possible moves for even a full ply searc=
h of depth 
  2<BR>> to yield any level of effectiveness.  The brea=
dth of<BR>> 
  available "legal" moves in Go starts at 361 and<BR>> s=
tays above 100 for 
  almost the entire game.  Worse,<BR>> thanks t=
o captures and Ko, the 
  number of legal moves<BR>> is not guaranteed t=
o descend.<BR><BR>This is a 
  very good idea!<BR><BR>I strongly suggest st=
aying away from full-board Go,

  the game ends if<BR>any stone o=
r stones are captured.)  There are no 
  KO's,<BR>and clearly finite l=
ength games, yet this game 
  is<BR>challenging.  (and you can move up=
 to 7x7)<BR><BR>Connect 4 seems 
  like a good game to work on.  Many<=

y vs. a computer.  There are only 7

he game is far from<BR>trivial.<BR><BR>> As

ism to priortize looking<BR>> at some subset of

ntial (if you<BR>> are familiar with Go, you could

t; patterns described in "Go Proverbs").  I suspect 
  an<BR>> ANN =
that specializes in small regional patterns will<BR>> likely 
  be able =
to be evolved that reduces the<BR>> "legal" move set 
  substantially.&n=
bsp; Even then, it would<BR>> need to reduce it to less 
  than 3% FOR E=
ACH PLY DEPTH<BR>> to make a ply search depth of 6 or 8 even 
  reasonab=
le<BR>> computationally.  That is one hell of an 
  efficiency,<BR>=
> +97% *accurate* reduction in legal moves.<BR>> <BR>> 
  At the p=
resent time, I am sort of seeing an ANN<BR>> sandwich; ANN #1 takes 
  a=
 set of all legal moves and<BR>> prioritizes them.  A ply manager 
=
  then recursively<BR>> calls ANN #1 until it reaches a certain depth.&n=
bsp; 
  Then<BR>> the ply manager presents the resultant board state<BR>=
> to ANN 
  #2 for a full board evaluation.  This cycle<BR>> con=
tinues until a 
  move is deemed most effective and<BR>> then utilized.<=
BR>> <BR>> The 
  way in which ANN #1 evolves (mutation and/or<BR>&gt=
; feedback on a fixed 
  topology, direct encoding using<BR>> NEAT, indi=
rect encoding using many 
  different types<BR>> of topological techniqu=
es including NEAT) can 
  be<BR>> completely different from the way in w=
hich ANN #2<BR>> 
  evolves.  This produces a meta-GA GA approach; =
a GA<BR>> for 
  discovering the ideal GA techinique for each of<BR>>=
 the two ANNs.  As 
  you can imagine, we now have a<BR>> HUGE comp=
utational space.  And 
  this assumes two ANNs<BR>> and some form o=
f the min-max algorithm.  
  And there<BR>> are other "techniques" =
for capturing static patterns<BR>> 
  in a pattern matching DB that migh=
t be more<BR>> efficient in the long 
  run.<BR><BR>Using more than one =

ammalian brain is<BR>organized in
